summary.abstract: This chapter examines the scholarly practices of Zoroastrian priests before and after the Islamic conquests, analyzing their engagement with Greek philosophy, the transmission of Pahlavi manuscripts, and the development of Zoroastrian theological literature in the Islamicate context. It traces the codification of Avestan and Pahlavi texts from the Sasanian period through the 14th century, mapping a network of priestly families and scribal communities in Iran (Kazerun, Nishapur, Sistan) and Gujarat. Special attention is given to the role of Ādurfarrbay ī Farrokhzādān and the Dēnkard as a turning point integrating Neoplatonic and Aristotelian philosophy into Zoroastrian theology. The chapter concludes by questioning whether Aristotelian influence in Pahlavi texts reflects Sasanian precedent or a 9th-century reformulation stimulated by encounters with the flourishing intellectual life of early Abbasid Baghdad.
